network.// comment-1: Initial proposal for I2RS attributes (to be discussed by the DT)
// network-id: I2RS definition is an URI (to be discussed by the DT)
The idea was to reflect into this attribute the provider-id, client-id and topology-id defined by TEAS
network.// supporting-network*: Not needed (to be discussed by the DT)
// ietf-te-topology:provider-id: TEAS definition is 'An identifier to uniquely identify a provider' (to be discussed by DT)
Syntax definition in te-types, copyed here:
An identifier to uniquely identify an operator, which can be
either a provider or a client.
The definition of this type is taken from RFC6370 and RFC5003.
This attribute type is used solely to provide a globally
RFC 5398 assigns the '64496-64511' and '65536-65551' ranges for documentation purposes
// ietf-te-topology:client-id: TEAS definition is 'An identifier to uniquely identify a client' (to be discussed by DT)
Clarification text from section 5.4 of draft-ietf-teas-yang-te-topo-09, copyed here:
Same syntax as the provider-id (defed in te-types)
when Customized TE Topologies come into play; a value of "0" is used
as the client-id for native TE Topologies
// ietf-te-topology:te-topology-id: TEAS definition is a string (to be discussed by DT)
Syntax definition in te-types, copyed here:
It is optional to have one or more prefixes at the begining,
separated by colons. The prefixes can be the network-types,
defined in ietf-network.yang, to help user to understand the
network.ietf-otn-topology:name: ODU Abstract Topology @ MPI
// node*: Updated with I2RS and some TEAS and OTN attributes:
Other nodes still to be updated

node.// comment-1: Initial proposal for I2RS attributes (to be discussed by the DT)
// node-id: I2RS definition is an URI (to be discussed by the DT)
It may be worthwhile reflecting into this attribute the te-node-id defined by TEAS
node.// supporting-node*: Not needed (to be discussed by the DT)
node.ietf-otn-topology:name: Node S3
// ietf-network-topology:termination-poi: Updated with I2RS and some TEAS and OTN attributes:
0) S3-1 LTP (terminating the access link to C-R1)
1) S3-2 LTP (terminating the link to S1)
Other LTPs still to be updated

// comment-1: It is assumed that this LTP is S3-1 LTP
which is terminating the access link to C-R1
This information was missing in the generated JSON code
ietf-network-topology:termination-point.// comment-2: Initial proposal for I2RS attributes (to be discussed by the DT)
// ietf-network-topology:tp-id: I2RS definition is an URI (to be discussed by the DT)
It may be worthwhile reflecting into this attribute the te-tp-id defined by TEAS
ietf-network-topology:termination-point.//supporting-termination-point*: Not needed (to be discussed by the DT)
// ietf-te-topology:te-tp-id: TEAS definition is either the LTP IP address or an unnumbered identifier (to be discussed by the DT)
Could we only use unnumbered identifiers?

state.name: LTP S3-1 terminating the access link to C-R1

// comment-1: It is assumed that this LTP is S3-2 LTP
which is terminating the internal link to S1

// ietf-network-topology:link*: Updated with I2RS and some TEAS and OTN attributes:
0) Access Link from S3 to C-R1
1) Access link from C-R1 to S3
3) Internal link from S1 to S3
Other links still to be updated

ietf-network-topology:link.// comment: Access Link from S3 to C-R1

ietf-network-topology:link.// destination: Not present because it is an egress access link (to be discussed by the DT)
// link-id: I2RS definition is an URI (to be discussed by the DT)
It may be worthwhile reflecting into this attribute the source or destination node and ltp
What could be the value if the destination node and ltp information is used instead?
We need different link-id values for the two unidirectional access links between S3 and C-R1
